examples.en: You can see a small rock two light years away from the moon.
examples.ja: 月からニ光年先に小さい石が見える。

examples.en: With this rocket it would take at least take 10,000 years to travel one light year.
examples.ja: このロケットで一光年先に行くとすると一万年はかかります。

examples.en: I wonder how many days it would take to travel one light year on a Segway.
examples.ja: 一光年はセグウェイで何日かかるんだろう。

meaning_mnemonic:
What happens when <kanji>light</kanji> travels a <kanji>year</kanji>? You have a <vocabulary>light-year</vocabulary>.

光年 is typically used after a number to specify the vast distances between celestial objects, like 地球からこの星まで3光年です (it's 3 light-years from Earth to this star).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The anti-nuclear movement believes that the abolition of nuclear weapons is feasible.
examples.ja: 核廃絶運動家たちは、核兵器を廃絶することは実現可能だと信じている。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>obsolete</kanji> will end in <kanji>extinction</kanji>. Join in the calls for its <vocabulary>abolition</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>elimination</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>extinction</vocabulary>, whatever it is.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Winter will continue for at least three more months in this mountain district.
examples.ja: この山岳地帯では、少なくともあと三ヶ月は冬の季節が続くだろうね。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>mountain</kanji> <kanji>peak</kanji>s are just the <vocabulary>mountains</vocabulary>. Just because you can only see the peaks doesn't mean the rest of the mountain doesn't exist.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meanings: To Let Someone Stay The Night

examples.en: I don't want to have some stranger stay at our house.
examples.ja: うちに知らない人を泊めるのは嫌です。

meaning_mnemonic: 泊まる is "to stay the night." Now you're letting someone else stay the night, which makes this <vocabulary>to let someone stay over</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to let someone stay the night</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 泊まる.

examples.en: Take your time. Other than needing to pee, there is no rush. One day at a time.
examples.ja: 焦るなよ。小便に行きたい以外は、急ぐ必要はないよ。一日一日を着実にな。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a bit of a weird word. The kanji is <kanji>char</kanji>, and a previous word you learned (焦げる) is "to be burned." This, on the other hand, is "to be in a hurry" or "to be impatient." I guess if you're getting burned or have that feeling, you're going <vocabulary>to be in a hurry</vocabulary> and you're going <vocabulary>to be impatient</vocabulary>. You can tell that this is that word because it only has one kana, る, which stands for <reading>ru</reading>de. You're feeling someone is being rude (or maybe you are), which is why you have this feeling of impatience and hurrying.
reading_mnemonic: You're being rude, but you're also being a big <reading>ass</reading> (あせ) with your impatience.

examples.en: I’ll let you know if I succeed in splitting up the couple.
examples.ja: あのカップルの仲をうまく引き裂く事ができたら、お知らせ致します。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 裂く is "to tear" or "to rip up." So, if you're trying to tear or rip up something, and you're <kanji>pull</kanji>ing it at the same time, you are going <vocabulary>to tear up</vocabulary> that thing, or more accurately perhaps <vocabulary>to tear off</vocabulary> something, since you're pulling.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 引く and 裂く.

examples.en: Can you make an easy-to-understand slide show on the process of nuclear fission?
examples.ja: 核分裂の過程について、分かりやすいスライドショーを作ってもらえますか。

meaning_mnemonic: 分裂 means "split" or "division." The <kanji>nucleus</kanji> version of this split is <vocabulary>nuclear fission</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Little did they know they would be able to attack titans by air.
examples.ja: 飛行機で巨人を襲撃することができるようになるとは、知る由もなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 襲撃 is an <kanji>assault</kanji> or <kanji>attack</kanji>? This is the verb form, so it's <vocabulary>to attack</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to assault</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: In Japan, having a long distance commute to school or work is pretty common.
examples.ja: 日本では、遠距離通学や遠距離通勤はよくあることです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>far</kanji> <kanji>distance</kanji> <kanji>detach</kanji>ment is a distance that is far. It is <vocabulary>long distance</vocabulary>. Also remember that 距離 is a "distance" so a far distance is a <vocabulary>long distance</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Taxi drivers generally dislike short distance trips, don’t they?
examples.ja: タクシーの運ちゃんは大体みんな近距離乗車は嫌がるよね。

meaning_mnemonic: A 距離 is a <kanji>distance</kanji> and 近 is <kanji>near</kanji>. A near distance is a <vocabulary>short distance</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Only years later did she finally admit she was the sprinter who won the short distance race.
examples.ja: ほんの数年後、彼女はようやく自分がその短距離走で優勝した短距離走者だったことを認めました。

meaning_mnemonic: A 距離 (<kanji>distance</kanji>) that is <kanji>short</kanji> is a <vocabulary>short distance</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We are planning to be entered in the family register before the wedding ceremony.
examples.ja: 結婚式の前に入籍をする予定です。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 戸籍 is the family register? This is referring to that, and that makes this word <vocabulary>entry in family register</vocabulary>. In most cases, that specifically means a <vocabulary>registration of marriage</vocabulary> in that family register.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The temporary workers are worried about being fired simultaneously in the recession.
examples.ja: 派遣社員たちは、景気の悪化で一斉に解雇されることを心配しています。

meaning_mnemonic: 一斉 is <kanji>simultaneous</kanji> or <kanji>all at once</kanji>. Add the に in there and you're heading towards those things. For "simultaneous" that becomes <vocabulary>simultaneously</vocabulary>. For "all at once" it stays at <vocabulary>all at once</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 一斉.

examples.en: If the earth is going to be destroyed, why should I resist eating bacon?
examples.ja: 地球がじきに滅びるんだとしたら、どうしてベーコンを食べるのを我慢しなくちゃいけないの？

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>destroy</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be destroyed</vocabulary>. You know you're not destroying things because of the <reading>beer</reading> (びる). You'd never destroy beer... but someone else might. Grrr.
reading_mnemonic: "THE <reading>HORROR</reading>!" (ほろ) you cry, as your beer is about <vocabulary>to be destroyed</vocabulary>.

examples.en: His muscles are as firm as rock.
examples.ja: 彼の筋肉は、岩のように硬い。

examples.en: The new model's expression was a little stiff with nervousness.
examples.ja: 新人モデルは、緊張で表情が少し硬くなっていた。

examples.en: Did you know that there are stones that are harder than diamonds?
examples.ja: ダイヤモンドよりも硬い石があることは、ご存知ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>stiff</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>stiff</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>hard</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>firm</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as a very similar word, 固い. So, if you can use that word to help you to remember, you'll remember the reading of this word in no time as well!

examples.en: I believe that psychological rigidity can hinder problem solving.
examples.ja: 心理的硬直は問題を解決する妨げになると思われる。

examples.en: The rigidity of society is a problem that we need to fix.
examples.ja: 社会の硬直化は解決しなければならない問題です。

examples.en: I wonder how long after death rigor mortis sets in.
examples.ja: 死後どのぐらいで死後硬直が起きるんでしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic:
Keep something <kanji>stiff</kanji> and <kanji>straight</kanji> and it's naturally going to lead to <vocabulary>stiffness</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>stiffening</vocabulary>.

硬直 commonly describes a person's body becoming stiff, whether from shock or discomfort, or due to the onset of rigor mortis following death.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Do you know how much more money the incumbent president earns than the former president?
examples.ja: 現職の大統領が、前大統領よりもどれだけ多くのお金を稼いでいるか知っているかい？

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>earnings</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to earn income</vocabulary>, because you can't "to income" something. Can also be <vocabulary>to make money</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: <vocabulary>To earn income</vocabulary>, you decided to start a <reading>car</reading> <reading>sa</reading>le. (かせ) "Every car sale, a step to richness!" was your quirky business mantra.

examples.en: The water in the pond was green yesterday, but it’s totally cleared up now. What happened?
examples.ja: 池の水、昨日は濁って緑色だったのに、今はすっかり澄んでいるじゃないか。一体何があったの？

meaning_mnemonic: Something with <kanji>lucidity</kanji> is clear. That's why this word is <vocabulary>to become clear</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to become transparent</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading when you learned the kanji.

examples.en: This beautiful spear is made from white gold and platinum.
examples.ja: この美しい矛は、白金とプラチナで作られています。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The person who's holding the <vocabulary>spear</vocabulary> is a little <reading>hoe 子</reading>. It's a child who learned to fight with a hoe, and he's turned the hoe into a <vocabulary>spear</vocabulary> to fight with. Imagine him swinging his hoe spear around like a little dork.

examples.en: Your skin will be really smooth after bathing in the hot spring.
examples.ja: その温泉に入った後は、お肌がツルツルになるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though you'll want to know that this refers most specifically to <vocabulary>human skin</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I get goosebumps just from hearing the name "cockroach."
examples.ja: 「ゴキブリ」という名前を聞くだけで、鳥肌が立ちます。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Bird</kanji> <kanji>skin</kanji> is <vocabulary>goosebumps</vocabulary>. Makes sense, since a goose is a bird and a bird's skin is bumpy.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the individual vocab readings of the two kanji, 鳥 and 肌.

examples.en: This towel is very soft and pleasant to the touch.
examples.ja: このタオルはとても柔らかくて心地よい肌触りです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>skin</kanji> <kanji>touch</kanji> is  the feeling of touching with your skin. That is <vocabulary>the touch of</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>feel of</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>texture</vocabulary> of something. It's what you feel when you touch your skin to something!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 肌 plus 触る's reading, combined. Watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: The woman's skin tone in this painting is very beautiful.
examples.ja: この絵の女性の肌色、すごく綺麗だね。

examples.en: I'm thinking of going with a light brown skin tone for this character.
examples.ja: このキャラクターの肌色は、明るい茶色にしようと思ってるんだ。

examples.en: The names of crayon and colored pencil colors that used to be called "skin tone" have now been changed to "pale orange" or "light orange."
examples.ja: 昔「肌色」って呼ばれてたクレヨンや色鉛筆の色の名前は、今は「ペールオレンジ」とか「うすだいだい」に変わってるんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Skin</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> is <vocabulary>skin color</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>skin tone</vocabulary>.

This word originally referred to a pale orange or peach color, and sometimes you'll still see it used that way. But labeling that as 肌色 wasn't inclusive of all skin tones. Now, it simply refers to skin color in general.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the vocab kun'yomi readings of each kanji, 肌 and 色 combined into one.

examples.en: The Pacific Ocean was filled with little boats.
examples.ja: 太平洋上には小舟がひしめきあっていた。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>boat</kanji> is a <vocabulary>boat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>small craft</vocabulary>. If something is a "big boat" it's better to call it a "ship" I think, which is why this is just a <vocabulary>boat</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are all ones you've seen before. 小 uses its こ reading, so just think of this like a "child boat." This makes sense because it's small. Watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: I destroyed the fishing boat with a hammer.
examples.ja: いさり舟をハンマーで叩いて破壊した。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Note that this word isn't usually used by itself (that would be 船). It's usually attached to things that are boat-related, but I wanted you to learn it individually so you can use it that way.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Also the same as 船.

examples.en: The bell rings twelve times at noon.
examples.ja: 正午になると鐘が12回鳴るんです。

examples.en: Hearing the bell calms my mind.
examples.ja: 鐘の音を聞くと心が落ち着きます。

examples.en: When I told him I was a tourist, he blatantly raised the price of the bell-shaped charm, but I felt a little sorry for him, so I held my tongue and paid the price he told me anyway.
examples.ja: 私が旅行者だと言うと、男は鐘の形をしたお守りの値段を明らかにつり上げたが、何だかそいつに悪い気がして、そのまま何も言わずに言われた通りの値段を払ったんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

鐘 usually refers to larger, open-ended <vocabulary>bell</vocabulary>s of the sort you might find in a church's bell tower or a Buddhist temple.
reading_mnemonic: Seeing the <vocabulary>bell</vocabulary>, you decide you need to ring it. You take your <reading>cane</reading> (かね) and hit the bell as hard as you can, making it chime.

examples.en: Researchers are sounding the alarm on how quickly the icebergs are melting.
examples.ja: 研究者たちは、どれだけ速く氷山が溶け出しているかについて警鐘を鳴らしている。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>warn</kanji> <kanji>bell</kanji> is a bell that goes off when you need to be warned about something. This is usually an <vocabulary>alarm bell</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>fire bell</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: As he screamed, "Achooo!" Koichi knocked the dangerous weapon from Viet’s hand.
examples.ja: 「アチョーーーーーー!」と叫び声を上げながら、コウイチはビエトの手から凶器を叩き落とした。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>villain</kanji> <kanji>vessel</kanji> is a vessel used by a villain. This vessel holds bullets, and is a <vocabulary>dangerous weapon</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The source of the terrible virus that wiped out half of mankind was a vodka-filled watermelon.
examples.ja: 人類の半分を一掃した凶悪なウィルスの元凶は、ウォッカのつまった西瓜だった。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>origin</kanji> <kanji>villain</kanji> is the villain who's running everything. They're the mastermind behind the villainy going on. They're the <vocabulary>ringleader</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>main culprit</vocabulary>.

元凶 isn't just limited to people, so it can often refer to the <vocabulary>root cause</vocabulary> of a problem too, like 汚染の元凶 (the main cause of pollution). It carries a serious, negative tone and is mostly used in writing about crimes, scandals, or other major issues.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned these, but since 元 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you out:

The <vocabulary>ringleader</vocabulary> of all these problems is <reading>Gen</reading>ji (げん). He's the <vocabulary>main culprit</vocabulary> behind this mess. Remember all that trouble he stirred up by flirting with too many women in "The Tale of Genji"? Everyone admired his beauty, but there's no doubt he was the <vocabulary>root cause</vocabulary> of a lot of chaos.

examples.en: Everyone believed that the atrocious criminal would not fare well in prison.
examples.ja: 誰もが、その凶悪犯が刑務所で大人しく刑期を務めるのは無理だろうと思っていました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>villain</kanji> who is <kanji>bad</kanji> is the most <vocabulary>atrocious</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>fiendish</vocabulary> villain of them all.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’ll be hunting in the mountains all of next week.
examples.ja: 来週はずっと山で狩りをしている予定です。

meaning_mnemonic: You have the noun version of <kanji>hunt</kanji>. That is <vocabulary>hunting</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading uses the reading from the kanji.

examples.en: I didn’t know the hunters used the five-day workweek system.
examples.ja: 狩人が週休二日制だってのは初耳だな。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>hunt</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a person who hunts. A <vocabulary>hunter</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You learned the reading of 狩 when you learned the kanji, but the reading for 人 is totally irregular. Just imagine that you're hunting a reindeer named <reading>Rudo</reading>lph (りゅうど). He has an unusually red nose, which makes him easy to spot and puts him at a bit of a disadvantage.

examples.en: Well, I'll call you again around 7 o'clock.
examples.ja: じゃあ、7時頃また電話しますよ。

examples.en: I was popular back then.
examples.ja: あの頃、俺は人気者だったんだよ。

examples.en: Around three o’clock this afternoon, a moon bear was seen in this park.
examples.ja: 今日のお昼の三時頃、この公園でツキノワグマが目撃されました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. When used as a suffix, it means <vocabulary>approximate time</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>around</vocabulary> (as in "around 3:00").
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Bear in mind that it's pronounced ころ when it's a noun, but it's usually ごろ when it's a suffix, though some people say ころ in both cases.

examples.en: We’d been good friends until just recently, but he suddenly grew really cold toward me. I don’t understand why.
examples.ja: つい先頃までとても仲良くしてたのに、彼が急によそよそしくなったんだけど、理由が全然分からないの。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>previous</kanji> <kanji>approximate</kanji> was the previous approximate time, which is <vocabulary>recently</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>the other day</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of the two kanji. That's 先 and 頃 (the reading you learned) put together. The 頃 is the rendaku'd version, ごろ so be careful.

examples.en: Recently I’ve been working the graveyard shift in a confectionery factory.
examples.ja: 近頃は製菓工場で夜勤の仕事をしているんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>near</kanji> <kanji>approximate</kanji> is the approximate time that was near to you. This period of time is the <vocabulary>lately</vocabulary> period of time. It's <vocabulary>recently</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 近い and 頃 put together.

examples.en: That kid's always alone, right? He doesn't seem to have friends his age so I can't help worrying about him.
examples.ja: あの子いつも一人だろう？彼、同じ年頃の友達がいないそうでどうも心配だ。

examples.en: Isn't it hard to take care of three adolescent kids?
examples.ja: 年頃の子が三人もいたら大変じゃない？

examples.en: My daughter has become old enough to get married, but seems to have absolutely no desire to do so, saying that she'd rather focus on her career.
examples.ja: うちの娘はもう年ごろなのに、キャリアに集中したいと言っていて、全然その気がないらしいのよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>year</kanji> <kanji>approximate</kanji> is your <vocabulary>approximate age</vocabulary>. This is also an indirect way to refer to <vocabulary>adolescence</vocabulary>, and when people reach <vocabulary>marriageable age</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the reading of the vocab version of 年 plus 頃, put together. Note: You will also sometimes see this written partially in kana like 年ごろ.

examples.en: How soon will Tofugu enter into the e-book market?
examples.ja: トーフグはいつ頃Eブックマーケットに参入するつもりですか？

meaning_mnemonic: いつ is "when" and 頃 is "about." Combine those together and you have "<vocabulary>about when</vocabulary>?" or "<vocabulary>how soon</vocabulary>?"
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, just rendaku'd.

examples.en: These days I’ve been adding chopped hazelnuts to my coffee for added flavor.
examples.ja: この頃、風味を出すために砕いたヘーゼルナッツを珈琲に加えてるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>This</kanji> (この) <kanji>approximate</kanji> is this approximate time. It is <vocabulary>recently</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>nowadays</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>these days</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the 頃 reading from the kanji reading. Be careful, it's the rendaku'd form.

examples.en: When I was young, I didn't care about what I ate, but now I do and I always add a little less sugar than the recipe calls for because my doctor told me that I'm at risk for diabetes.
examples.ja: 若い頃は食べ物について気にしなかったけど、今はお医者さんに糖尿病予備軍だって言われたので、食べ物に気をつけるようになったし、いつもレシピに書かれてるよりも少ない砂糖を入れるようにもなりました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>young</kanji> <kanji>approximate</kanji> is the approximate age of when you were young. This, approximately, is <vocabulary>one's youth</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>early life</vocabulary>.

若い頃 is often used when fondly remembering the past, like, "When I was younger, I used to…"
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 若い and 頃 combined into one.

examples.en: The video about the little angel and the bacon deeply moved my soul.
examples.ja: 小さな天使とベーコンのビデオを観て、魂が震えました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Look inside your <kanji>soul</kanji>. You see all the bits and bobs that make up your <vocabulary>soul</vocabulary> rolling around and around, being pushed by the Katamari <reading>Tamashii</reading> (たましい). He keeps your soul nice and big and safe!

examples.en: I asked Aya to draw an illustration to offer to the souls of the dead.
examples.ja: 死者の霊魂に捧げる為のイラストを描いてほしいとアヤに頼みました。

meaning_mnemonic: When attached to a word, this refers to a ____ spirit. It's  the same meaning as the kanji, too.
reading_mnemonic: This word is made up of a single kanji, but it uses the on'yomi reading, not the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, you've learned this reading already. Yay!

examples.en: My legs are restless at night and I can’t sleep well.
examples.ja: 夜になると脚がムズムズして、よく眠れないんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Wondering how 脚 and 足 differ? You might remember 足 is mostly for feet but can sometimes refer to legs. 脚 refers to the whole <vocabulary>leg</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>lower limb</vocabulary> (often including the foot). Basically, go with 足 for feet and 脚 for legs!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 足!

examples.en: What the other scripts weren’t able to do, his script did.
examples.ja: 他の脚本では出来なかった事を、彼の脚本はやってのけたんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>leg</kanji> <kanji>book</kanji> is just the legs of a book. Not a whole book. It only contains the parts that walk around and move, not so much the descriptions (things that don't move). This kind of book is a <vocabulary>script</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>screenplay</vocabulary>. These "books" are focused on actions and things people say, which is why it's just the legs.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I was quite surprised when I bumped into my first love in Japan.
examples.ja: 日本で初恋の人にバッタリ出くわした時は、可也驚きました。

meaning_mnemonic: It's <kanji>possible</kanji> that it's <kanji>considerably</kanji> considerable. It's <vocabulary>considerably</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>fairly</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>quite</vocabulary>... something. Also please note that this is almost always written in kana and not kanji. But, we're learning kanji here, so gosh darn it we're going to learn some kanji.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: The witch put a curse on the princess that made it so she could only hold cups upside down.
examples.ja: 魔女はお姫様に、コップを逆さまにしか持てなくする呪いをかけた。

meaning_mnemonic: Despite looking like an adjective this is a noun. It means the same thing as the kanji: <vocabulary>curse</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: After my husband was diagnosed with Post Traumatic Stress Disorder I cursed whoever it was that started the war.
examples.ja: 夫が心的外傷後ストレス障害と診断された後、私はそれが誰であれその戦争を始めた人を呪いました。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>curse</kanji>, and the verb version is <vocabulary>to curse</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to put a curse on</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Our company’s business days follow the regular calendar.
examples.ja: うちの会社は暦通りの営業になります。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: When looking at a calendar, the <reading>子読み</reading> (こよみ) of it is to... well... not be able to read it at all. Because, children can't really read. So, when you look at a calendar you have to explain it to a child, since they cannot read it.

examples.en: When will it be the lunar calendar’s New Year?
examples.ja: 旧暦の正月といえばいつになりますかね。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>former</kanji> <kanji>calendar</kanji> is the calendar from before. It's the <vocabulary>lunisolar calendar</vocabulary> and the <vocabulary>traditional Japanese calendar</vocabulary>. Certainly not the current calendar, anyways.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: What year in the Western calendar did the Showa era end?
examples.ja: 昭和は西暦何年に終わったんですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
In the <kanji>west</kanji>, a <kanji>calendar</kanji> shows the year according to the <vocabulary>common era</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>Christian era</vocabulary>. You know, like 2025 CE (or 2025 AD) — we're 2000+ years into the common era.

This <vocabulary>Western calendar</vocabulary> differs from the traditional calendar of Japan, which names its eras for reigning emperors. The current Reiwa era followed the Heisei era, which came after the Showa era. Neat, right? On official forms in Japan, you can often choose whether to write your birth year in the Western or Japanese style.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The sky suddenly got cloudy.
examples.ja: 空が急に曇ってきた。

examples.en: Oh no! The windshield is fogged up and I can't see outside.
examples.ja: やばい！フロントガラスが曇って外が見えない。

examples.en: I don't like it when ramen steam fogs up my glasses.
examples.ja: ラーメンの湯気で眼鏡が曇っちゃうのが好きじゃないんだよね。

examples.en: As we talked, my girlfriend's expression gradually darkened.
examples.ja: 話しているうちに、彼女の表情が少しずつ曇っていった。

examples.en: I think my judgment was clouded by the respect and admiration I felt for him.
examples.ja: 彼への尊敬や憧れで目が曇っていたのだと思います。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cloudy</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to get cloudy</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to become cloudy</vocabulary>.

Aside from describing the weather, 曇る can also refer to other physical phenomena, like when your glasses or bathroom mirror gets fogged up. It can also be used figuratively, such as when someone's expression clouds over (表情が曇る) due to a negative emotion.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. It also happens to be the same as 雲, which has a very similar meaning (clouds).

examples.en: Cloudy days are actually better for photography than bright afternoon sunlight.
examples.ja: 実は、眩しい午後の日差しの下よりも、曇りの日の方が写真撮影には適しています。

examples.en: Cloudy weather means that more than 90% of the sky is covered in clouds.
examples.ja: 曇りとは、空の９割以上が雲でおおわれている状態のことです。

examples.en: I'm having trouble defogging the windows.
examples.ja: 窓の曇りが中々とれない。

meaning_mnemonic:
The noun version of <kanji>cloudy</kanji> is <vocabulary>cloudy weather</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cloudiness</vocabulary>. In some cases, this can also refer to the type of <vocabulary>fog</vocabulary> you'd find on a window or your glasses.

Despite being a noun in Japanese, you'll actually see this translated as the adjective "cloudy" in English a lot. Don't let that fool you, though, it still behaves as a noun in Japanese! It's just another example of word types not quite matching up between English and Japanese.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: My nephew likes watching the Shinkansen so much that he can stare at it all day long.
examples.ja: うちの甥っ子は新幹線を見るのが好きで、一日中眺めていることもできます。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stare</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to stare at</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>to look at</vocabulary> in a very staringish way).
reading_mnemonic: To learn the reading, just think about how you're looking at something for a lonnnnng time if you're staring at it. In Japanese the word "long" is 長い, and guess what the reading of the kanji part is? It's なが, just like <reading>なが</reading>める's kanji-part reading.

examples.en: We were able to view the beautiful blue ocean from our hotel room.
examples.ja: そのホテルの部屋からは美しく青い海を眺望することができました。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>stare</kanji> at <kanji>hope</kanji>. It looks good. That is your <vocabulary>prospect</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>view</vocabulary>, as you stare at hope.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: You only live once! Come on. You should go skydiving nude with me. It would be a great experience for us.
examples.ja: 一度しかない人生だろ！なぁ！一緒に全裸でスカイダイビングしに行こうぜ。すんげぇいい経験になると思うんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: You're <kanji>all</kanji> <kanji>naked</kanji>, which makes you <vocabulary>completely naked</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>totally naked</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Ahh! My dream just came true! It was the dream where a half naked hunk said "Good morning" the moment I woke up, while drinking freshly brewed coffee!
examples.ja: きゃー！たった今夢が叶っちゃった！半裸のイケメンが淹れたての珈琲を飲みながら、私が目を覚ました瞬間に「おはよう」って言ってくれるっていう夢が！

meaning_mnemonic: If you're <kanji>half</kanji> <kanji>naked</kanji> you're <vocabulary>half nude</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>half naked</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Gross! I just saw a naked dude wearing just a sleeveless apron at the crosswalk over there. Should we call the police?
examples.ja: キモイ！今あそこの横断歩道で、裸に袖無しエプロンを着た男を見かけたんだけど。警察に通報した方がいいかな。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: You are <vocabulary>naked</vocabulary> now. You used to wear a car, but you don't have it anymore (and you're not wearing it). You <reading>had a ca</reading>r (はだか), but now you don't have a car. That's what you'll explain when someone asks you why you're naked.

examples.en: She gambles considerable amounts of money at the horse races.
examples.ja: 彼女は競馬で、中々の大金を賭けるんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>gamble</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to gamble</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I won a bet against him.
examples.ja: あいつとの賭けに勝ったよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The noun version of <kanji>gamble</kanji> is <vocabulary>gambling</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>betting</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>a gamble</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>a bet</vocabulary>. Whatever you do, put it all on black 13. Trust me.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: What’s the matter with your cram school?
examples.ja: 塾に何か問題でもあるの？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned in the kanji.

examples.en: I felt completely out of place on my first day of private school.
examples.ja: 義塾に通い始めた初日、思いっきり場違いだと感じました。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>righteousness</kanji> <kanji>cram school</kanji> is, for some reason, a <vocabulary>private school</vocabulary>. Maybe because they don't think the public cram schools are any good, so they take their righteousness somewhere else to start a private one? I'm not sure.

You may have seen the abbreviation 私学 (for 私立学校) as another word for private school. 私学 is typically used for any schools, elementary through university, that are run by individuals or private groups.

義塾 instead generally describes private schools founded during the Edo and Meiji periods. In contemporary Japanese, it's not really used on its own but can be seen in school names like 明徳義塾高等学校 (Meitoku Gijuku High School).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: He had the worst memory out of all the cram school students.
examples.ja: 彼は塾生たちの中で一番記憶力が悪かった。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 学生 is "student"? This plays off that. A <kanji>cram school</kanji> "student" is a student of a cram school, a <vocabulary>cram school student</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please stop drumming on the calculator. You’re driving me crazy!
examples.ja: 頼むから電卓を叩くのをやめてくれ。気が狂いそうになるだろ！

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>table</kanji> is a <vocabulary>calculator</vocabulary>. Why is this? You can think about it in a couple of different ways. Maybe in the past, a calculator (aka abacus) would take up a whole table, making this "electric" version a calculator. Or, maybe it can be used to solve tables. Wrong kind of table, but should help you to remember the meaning of this word.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’ll wash the dishes and you can clear the table for me. Is that okay?
examples.ja: 私がお皿を洗うから、あなたは食卓を綺麗にしてくれる？いいかしら？

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>eat</kanji>ing <kanji>table</kanji> is a <vocabulary>dining table</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There is a Mahjong table in my house if you want to play.
examples.ja: 麻雀するなら、うちに雀卓があるけど。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: That ping pong noise is driving me crazy!
examples.ja: あの卓球の音のせいで気が変になりそうだ！

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Table</kanji> <kanji>sphere</kanji> is a sport where you have a table and then you use a sphere on it. That's <vocabulary>table tennis</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>ping pong</vocabulary>. Makes sense, right? You use a ping pong ball and you play on a table.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of たく's shortening.

examples.en: Why are you polishing a light bulb that’s already burnt out?
examples.ja: 何で切れた電球なんか磨いてるの？

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>polish</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to polish</vocabulary> or, strangely specifically (and we'll learn an even more specific word for this later) <vocabulary>to brush your teeth</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I am hoping to find a job by polishing up my Excel skills.
examples.ja: Excelのスキルに磨きをかけて、仕事が見つかればいいな、と思っています。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>polish</kanji> is a <vocabulary>polish</vocabulary> or even a <vocabulary>shine</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Recently, I started seriously studying bacteria.
examples.ja: 最近真剣に細菌について勉強をし始めました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>thin</kanji> <kanji>bacteria</kanji> is... well... a <vocabulary>bacteria</vocabulary>. I guess all bacteria are really thin. So thin you can't see them with your naked eye, in fact.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

examples.en: Even though I’m homeless, it’s really irritating when people stare at me like I’m some kind of germ.
examples.ja: ホームレスだからって、俺がまるでばい菌のように人にジロジロ見られるのは、とても腹立たしい。

meaning_mnemonic: A "ばい" <kanji>bacteria</kanji> is a <vocabulary>germ</vocabulary>. In case you're wondering, the ばい is referring to the kanji 黴, but people don't usually write that part.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I just got an email asking whether or not the Tofugu stickers are sterilized.
examples.ja: トーフグのステッカーが無菌かどうかの問い合わせのメールが来たんだけど。

meaning_mnemonic: Someplace with <kanji>nothing</kanji> amounts of <kanji>bacteria</kanji> is <vocabulary>sterilized</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>aseptic</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: What’s the best way to sterilize a bathroom?
examples.ja: トイレを殺菌する一番いい方法は何ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>kill</kanji> <kanji>bacteria</kanji> you are performing <vocabulary>sterilization</vocabulary>. You're killing those bacteria.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening.

examples.en: Can’t you stop making fun of me behind my back? If you have something to say, say it to my face.
examples.ja: 陰でこそこそ私の陰口言うの、止めてくれない？言いたいことがあるなら、はっきり言ってよ！

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Also means <vocabulary>shadow</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Look at a <vocabulary>shadow</vocabulary>. It's long, surprisingly long. It's in the shape of a <reading>cage</reading> (かげ), because that's what is producing the long shadow. Check out each bar of the cage. Maybe you're inside the cage? Whatever is going on, a long shadow is being created by the cage and shade.

examples.en: I was certain he was a melancholy guy until I saw his Youtube videos.
examples.ja: アイツのYoutubeビデオを見るまでは、てっきり陰気な男だと思っていたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>shade</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> is a shady feeling. It's a feeling of <vocabulary>gloom</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>melancholy</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: She drove speeding through the tunnel because she heard there was an evil spirit in there.
examples.ja: 悪霊がいると聞いたので、トンネルの中ではスピードを上げて運転しました。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>evil</kanji> <kanji>ghost</kanji> isn't so much a ghost as it is an <vocabulary>evil spirit</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Note this uses the secondary 霊 reading of りょう, so imagine an evil spirit rowing a boat.

examples.en: She’s a spiritual person with a strong sixth sense and can talk to people on the other side.
examples.ja: 彼女は非常に霊感の強い霊能力者で、あの世の人と話をすることができます。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>ghost</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji> is <vocabulary>inspiration</vocabulary>. For some reason, the feeling of ghosts is the feeling of inspiration. I guess a ghost goes inside you and makes you feel this inspiration? Oh, wait, you can feel that because you have the <vocabulary>sixth sense</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The ghost continued to scare people without getting depressed.
examples.ja: 亡霊はめげずに、人々を怖がらせ続けました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>deceased</kanji> <kanji>ghost</kanji> is a <vocabulary>ghost</vocabulary> (all ghosts are deceased). Can also refer to "<vocabulary>the dead</vocabulary>."
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My family took our puppy to a pet cemetery.
examples.ja: 家族でうちの犬をペット専用霊園に連れて行きました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>ghost</kanji> <kanji>garden</kanji> is where many ghosts are harvested and where many ghosts grow. This is a <vocabulary>cemetery</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Something has been wrong with my humidifier.
examples.ja: 最近加湿器の調子が悪いんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: An "<kanji>add</kanji> <kanji>damp</kanji>ness <kanji>container</kanji>" is a container that adds dampness to the air. That's a <vocabulary>humidifier</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: If I am not mistaken, there are a lot of wetlands in Hokkaido, right?
examples.ja: 確か、北海道には湿地が多いんだよね？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>damp</kanji> <kanji>earth</kanji> is where water seems to congregate, but not so much that there's a lake or ocean or anything like that. Just damp. This is a <vocabulary>wetlands</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I don’t like the rainy season in Japan because it’s very humid.
examples.ja: 日本の梅雨は湿気が多いので嫌いです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>damp</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> is a feeling of dampness. It is <vocabulary>moisture</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>humidity</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be careful of the shortening, and the irregular reading for 気.

examples.en: I sweat a lot when I was sleeping last night and my bed is a little damp.
examples.ja: 昨日の夜、寝汗をたくさんかいちゃったから、ベッドが何だか湿ってるのよね。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>damp</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be damp</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be moist</vocabulary>. Ewww.
reading_mnemonic: You know what's really damp and moist? <reading>Shee</reading>p <reading>me</reading>n (しめ) are. They've been hanging out in a greenhouse and now their wool is all damp. They're going to need a towel to dry off.

examples.en: My wife gets upset with me whenever I wear my socks inside out.
examples.ja: 靴下を裏返しに履いちゃうと、嫁が怒ってうるさいんだわ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Around the time they got married, my son’s wife pretended she was a prude.
examples.ja: 嫁ぎたての頃は、息子の嫁はかまととぶっていました。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bride</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to marry</vocabulary>, because you can't really "to bride" someone.

嫁ぐ is often used when describing how someone has or is going <vocabulary>to marry into</vocabulary> another family.
reading_mnemonic: Imagine you're getting married to a valley girl. You're all like. Hey, I'm gonna marry you! And she's all like <reading>Tots</reading> (とつ), we gonna get, like, married! Imagine her saying more "tots" things (tots = short for totally in valley girl speak, at least in my imagination).

examples.en: I found a 10,000 yen bill in a ditch beside a coin operated parking space.
examples.ja: コインパーキングの横の溝に、万札が落ちてるのを見つけたんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

溝 is commonly used for physical gaps like drainage ditches, small trenches, or grooves in surfaces. It can also describe metaphorical gaps, like emotional or relational divides between people.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you step in that <vocabulary>gutter</vocabulary> you'll catch <reading>measle</reading>s (みぞ). A gutter or <vocabulary>ditch</vocabulary> has all kinds of dirt and germs in it, including measles, so don't go stepping in it or drinking from it!

examples.en: I wonder if Filipinos know that the spawning place for eels is close to the Philippine Trench.
examples.ja: 鰻がフィリピン海溝の近くで産卵することは、フィリピン人に知られているのでしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>ocean</kanji> <kanji>gutter</kanji> is an <vocabulary>ocean trench</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I fell into a drainage ditch and got injured.
examples.ja: 排水溝に落ちて怪我をした。

examples.en: It's pretty common for even Japanese people to mix up 排水溝 and 排水口, isn't it?
examples.ja: 排水溝と排水口がごっちゃになってる人って日本人でも結構多いよね。

examples.en: It's important to clean the gutters and drainage ditches regularly because it can be a big hassle when they get clogged.
examples.ja: 詰まると大変だから、側溝や排水溝は定期的に掃除しておいた方がいいですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You already know that <kanji>emit</kanji>ted <kanji>water</kanji> means "drainage." Add <kanji>gutter</kanji> to that and this becomes a <vocabulary>drainage</vocabulary> in the sense of a <vocabulary>drainage ditch</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>gutter</vocabulary>.

When it comes to the drain in your sink or bathtub, you can use 排水口, which has the same pronunciation but a different kanji.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The top team will be awarded with a prize of doing aesthetic waterfall meditation.
examples.ja: 一位のチームには、賞品として滝修行が授与されます。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: My grandma told me that it is very dangerous to swim in the rapids.
examples.ja: 祖母に、滝川を泳ぐのは危険だと言われました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>waterfall</kanji> <kanji>river</kanji> is a river that's moving like a waterfall! Fast and furious! Water that moves like this are <vocabulary>rapids</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab reading of each kanji: 滝 and 川. Careful of the rendaku.

examples.en: "Salmon, let’s get married in Las Vegas this weekend." "Fugu, have you lost your mind?"
examples.ja: 「サーモン、今週末、ラスベガスで結婚しよう。」「フグ、気でも狂ったの？」

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lunatic</kanji> or <kanji>crazy</kanji>. The verb version of this is <vocabulary>to go mad</vocabulary> (you don't really "go lunatic" now, do you?) or <vocabulary>to go crazy</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: To remember the reading, just think about how when you go crazy, you are <reading>coming</reading> (来る) to crazy town. Just imagine some voice beckoning you to come. Come here! Please come here! Come to crazy town! Give in to the voices!

examples.en: You must be insane to decline that offer.
examples.ja: その申し出を断るなんて狂気の沙汰だよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Lunatic</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> is <vocabulary>madness</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>insanity</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: It looked just like a phoenix soaring high in the air.
examples.ja: それは、まるで天空を高く翔る不死鳥のようでした。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>fly</kanji>, so the verb version means <vocabulary>to fly</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading already! You should be able to read this too!

examples.en: My mom forbade my dad from collecting tasteless dolls.
examples.ja: 母は、父が悪趣味な人形を集めることを禁止しました。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 趣味 means "hobby"? Well, if you have <kanji>bad</kanji> hobbies, it probably means you have <vocabulary>bad taste</vocabulary>. 

悪趣味 is often used to describe something that lacks sophistication or sensitivity, like tacky shoes and offensive jokes, as well as someone with that kind of taste.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There is braille on this wrapping paper.
examples.ja: この包み紙には点字が施してあるわ。

meaning_mnemonic: A 包み is a <kanji>bundle</kanji> or <kanji>package</kanji>, and 紙 is <kanji>paper</kanji>. What paper goes around bundles and packages? That would be <vocabulary>wrapping paper</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 包み and 紙 combined together. Be careful of rendaku.

examples.en: It’s high time we got out of here. Let’s move.
examples.ja: そろそろ潮時だ。引き上げるぞ。

examples.en: It’s high time that you quit smoking. Go get some nicotine patches right now.
examples.ja: 今こそタバコをやめる潮時だ。今すぐニコチンパッチを買いに行くんだ。

examples.en: The man decided to take this as an opportunity to step down from his gig as a legal drug seller, as he knew that he might put himself in danger someday if he continued to do this.
examples.ja: こんなことを続けていては、いつか自分の身を危険にさらすかもしれないと、男はこれを潮時に合法ドラッグの売り子からは身を引く事にした。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>tide</kanji> <kanji>time</kanji> is the <vocabulary>tidal hour</vocabulary>.

This word is often used figuratively, as in “the perfect time to act”, especially in reference to quitting something or backing away from a situation.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the individual words, 潮 and 時. Watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: Where exactly is the basin of the Kuroshio Current?
examples.ja: 黒潮の流域とは正確にはどこになりますか？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>black</kanji> <kanji>tide</kanji> isn't what you think, most likely. This is the <vocabulary>Japan current</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>Kuroshio Current</vocabulary>. It's a Northern flowing  current on the West side of the Pacific Ocean. Have you heard of the Gulf Stream? It's kind of like that.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the two kanji, put together. 黒 and 潮.

examples.en: I was rubbing my eyes because of my allergies and one of my contact lenses was torn.
examples.ja: 花粉症で目を擦ってたら、片方のコンタクトレンズが破けました。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>rub</kanji> and this verb means <vocabulary>to rub</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to scrub</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
If you're going <vocabulary>to rub</vocabulary> me like that, I'm going to <reading>sue</reading> (す) you. It's making me very uncomfortable. The <reading>cos</reading>t  (こす) of your rubbing actions will be high.
    
So this word has two readings and both mean “to rub.” But you usually use する for a single action, such as lighting a match or grazing your knee, while こする means doing it repeatedly, like when you’re cleaning or polishing something.

examples.en: This package is just a symbol of our friendship.
examples.ja: この小包は、ほんの友情の印です。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>bundle</kanji> is merely a <vocabulary>package</vocabulary>. Something big would be a big package, I guess.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 小 (which is a reading you've seen a couple times now, I'm sure) and 包み, with the み pushed inside the package. Beware of the somewhat weird rendaku. You don't see づ too often.

examples.en: The one hundred erasers that I had collected were melted by the heat and turned into one big lump.
examples.ja: コレクションしていた消しゴム100個が熱で溶けて一つの大きな塊になってしまった。

examples.en: When I went into the store, the first thing I noticed was the lump of meat that was placed on the counter.
examples.ja: 店に入ると、カウンターにドンと置かれた肉の塊がまず一番に目についた。

examples.en: That con man is the embodiment of an inferiority complex.
examples.ja: その詐欺師は劣等感の塊だった。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are the same, so this can mean <vocabulary>lump</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>mass</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>bundle</vocabulary>. Additionally, this can also refer to being the <vocabulary>embodiment</vocabulary> of something. When somebody or something is a mass or bundle of some attribute or trait, they might as well be the embodiment of it!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Recognize this word?

examples.en: This is a reasonable price, isn’t it?
examples.ja: 手頃な値段ですね。

meaning_mnemonic: When you control your <kanji>hand</kanji> an <kanji>approximate</kanji> amount, you are going to be a very <vocabulary>moderate</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>reasonable</vocabulary> person.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I'm tormented by feelings of helplessness.
examples.ja: 無力感に苛まれてるんよ。

examples.en: The sweltering heat torments us.
examples.ja: うだるような暑さが私達を苛む。

examples.en: The victims were tormented by the anxiety that something else bad would happen.
examples.ja: 被害者はまた何か悪いことが起こるのではないかという不安に苛まれていました。

meaning_mnemonic: As usual, you can guess this is a verb thanks to the う sound on the end. The kanji means <kanji>frustration</kanji>, and unfortunately frustration tends <vocabulary>to torment</vocabulary> people. This verb is pretty advanced, but still useful to know!
reading_mnemonic: We all know it's not okay to <vocabulary>to torment</vocabulary> each other. So how about we all <reading>sign a</reading> (さいな) contract saying that we'll never torment anyone ever again?

examples.en: The servants who serve in this house are very polite.
examples.ja: この家に仕える使用人は、とても礼儀が正しい。

examples.en: The woman seemed to be a female official in the service of the Meiji Emperor.
examples.ja: その女性は、明治天皇に仕えていた女官のようです。

examples.en: Nice to meet you. I'm an angel who started serving God today.
examples.ja: はじめまして。今日から神に仕えることになった天使です。

meaning_mnemonic:
Everything we're <kanji>doing</kanji> is <vocabulary>to serve</vocabulary> you, you know.

This verb is a bit archaic and therefore has a formal feel to it. It's used to talk about serving emperors, kings, and gods, among others.
reading_mnemonic: <vocabulary>To serve</vocabulary> you well, we've gotten ourselves <reading>two ca</reading>rs (つか). If one breaks down, we can still serve you with the other car.

examples.en: Please insert a ten-yen or hundred-yen coin.
examples.ja: 十円または百円硬貨を入れてください。

examples.en: My grandmother saved coins in her wallet.
examples.ja: 祖母は財布の中に硬貨を貯めていました。

examples.en: What are some coins that are no longer being produced?
examples.ja: もう製造されていない硬貨にはどんなものがありますか。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Stiff</kanji> <kanji>freight</kanji> always has to be paid for in <vocabulary>coin</vocabulary>s, because coins are also stiff. You can't go paying for something stiff with something not stiff, that would make no sense at all.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I need to start thinking about the menu for tonight.
examples.ja: そろそろ今晩の献立を考えないと。

examples.en: It is difficult to come up with a menu that will please everyone.
examples.ja: 全員に喜んでもらえる献立を考えるのは難しい。

examples.en: I always do my weekly meal plan by looking at the contents of my refrigerator.
examples.ja: 私は、いつも冷蔵庫の中身を見て一週間の献立を立てます。

meaning_mnemonic:
I will <kanji>offer</kanji> you food and <kanji>stand</kanji> here while you eat it, because I curated this <vocabulary>menu</vocabulary> and I want to make sure you enjoy it.

This word doesn't mean the physical menu you get in a restaurant; rather, it refers to a <vocabulary>meal plan</vocabulary>, whether that means the sequence of courses for a single meal or the general meal plan for someone's entire week.
reading_mnemonic:
You didn't learn this reading for 献 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The most special thing about the <vocabulary>menu</vocabulary> I curated for you? It's all <reading>con</reading>dor (こん) meat: deep-fried condor wings, condor yakitori, condor foie gras. As scavengers, condors aren't exactly the safest birds to put on a menu, so I'm going to stand here just in case you get sick and keel over mid-meal.
